column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=custom.Span|label
#T_RL=custom.Relation|label|BT_custom.Span
#Text=In the case of Edgar
#Text=there was a constitutional condition upon which was grafted a
#Text=localized affection of the left lung.
#Text=This was probably a lobar
#Text=broncho-pneumonia in the first instance, like those just described,
#Text=with pleurisy, the result of which was a cartilaginous degeneration
#Text=of the pleura and a fibroid degeneration of the lung.
#Text=We may
#Text=look upon the fetid cavity, therefore, as consecutive to those fibroid
#Text=degenerations, just as in ordinary phthisis a vomica is consecutive
#Text=to tuberculization.
#Text=And I think that when we find such cavities
#Text=in a highly fibroid lung, we may reasonably conclude that they are
#Text=formed like other ulcerous solutions of continuity of tissues in the
#Text=state of fibroid degeneration, and are to he classed with rodent
#Text=fibroid ulcers in the skin and cervix uteri or elsewhere.
#Text=Hence
#Text=the cavity is the result of rodent fibroid ulceration.
#Text=In its lining
#Text=pyogenic membrane there is a tissue analogous to that of the
#Text=bronchial mucous membrane in cases of chronic bronchitis.
#Text=Since
#Text=the structural disease is constitutional, it is fair to conclude that
#Text=the predisposing causes of the peculiar fetid excretion are constitutional, and are linked etiologically with the fibroid change of
#Text=tissue.
#Text=It is a special characteristic of fibroid and cartilaginous
#Text=ulcerations to be fetid.
#Text=This is well shown in ozaena, which is a
#Text=deep ulceration of the fibrous and cartilaginous tissues of the nose,
#Text=and also in rodent fibroid ulcers in general.
#Text=The smell of ozaena
#Text=is, in fact, very similar to that observed in examples of fetid fibroid
#Text=vomicai ; and M.
#Text=Lasagne correctly remarks the same of the fetor
#Text=in fetid bronchitis.
#Text=Yet it is not otherwise described by observers
#Text=in general than as " gangrenous."
#Text=The characters will doubtless differ in different cases, according to the complications, — in one
#Text=there may be dilated bronchi ; in another, a gangrenous cavern ; in
#Text=another, blood may be exuded and decompose in tlie cavity
#Text=under the same kind of fermentation as that which modifies the pus
#Text=and bronchial secretion.
#Text=The smell might well be termed an ozaena-odour.
#Text=The Nature and Origin of the Pulmonary Fetor in Fetid Bronchitis and Bronchorrhoea.
#Text=In the last group of cases I have endeavoured to show that the
#Text=peculiar fetor is probably similar in origin to ozaena ; but it is not
#Text=like that odour in all cases ; nor will the explanation apply to the
#Text=fetor of acute and chronic bronchitis, or of bronchorrhoea, or
#Text=broncho-pneumonia, for tliere is no proof of a rodent ulcerous cavity
#Text=in these.
#Text=Now, it is to be observed that the odour is sui generis
#Text=in them, as compared with other pulmonary fetors, and has therefore its own characters.
#Text=1.
#Text=In its typical form, according to my experience, when it comes directly from the lung, it is always more
#Text=or less faecal.
#Text=In the first case that I observed, the breath and
#Text=sputa rendered a spacious ward odious as a privy, with the stench
#Text=of fresh foeces.
#Text=As to this fact there can be no mistake.
#Text=Now this
#Text=is not the odour of the breath in cases of fetid abscess or ozaena.
#Text=2.
#Text=After the sputa has been exposed to the air for a while, however,
#Text=it gives off an odour wholly different.
#Text=In my first case I could
#Text=only liken it to the delicate scent of a decaying apple.- In the
#Text=case of Oliver S.
#Text=(reported by my friend Dr Low of King ' s Lynn,
#Text=together with my clinical remarks), the breath and sputa were
#Text=noted as of an odour "rather faecal than gangrenous;" while that
#Text=of the sputa became like the scent of the apple or hawthorn blossom.
#Text=And in the case of C.
#Text=A., the sputum is correctly described as " of
#Text=a muco-purulent character, with a disagreeable faecal odour, which
#Text=is most intense when just expectorated, and which, on standing
#Text=exposed to the air, becomes changed, — sometimes into a wet-mortar
#Text=smell, but more generally into what simulates apple-blossom very
#Text=closely."
#Text=Now, in these characteristics the odour of fetid bronchitis differs essentially from that of fetid abscess and of true
#Text=pulmonary gangrene.
#Text=In the case of pulmonary gangi-ene with
#Text=which I compared my first example of fetid bronchitis, the breath
#Text=was so horrible that I was made sick to vomiting when using tlie
#Text=stethoscope.
#Text=It was wholly unlike that of faeces.
#Text=All writers
#Text=speak of this dreadful smeii in true pulmonary gangrene; but
#Text=none ever describe it as faecal except Louis.
#Text=He informed M.
#Text=Valleix that he had observed exceptions to this hon-ible putrid
#Text=smell in certain cases, in which the odour resembled that of feces,
#Text=although after death there was nothing more observed in the lung
#Text=than what is usually found.
#Text=I suspect, however, that these cases
#Text=were examples of pyogenic cavities, or dilated bronchi, and not
#Text=gangrene ; for it is probable these pyogenic membranes give forth
#Text=the same purulent stuff as the bronchial mucous membrane in cases
#Text=of fetid bronchitis.
#Text=Dr EUiotson remarks incidentally, that in
#Text=phthisis the expectoration sometimes smells " like fasces."
#Text=I must
#Text=express a doubt, however, that these were cases of tubercular
#Text=phthisis, for I have never observed the faecal odour in any such
#Text=cases.
#Text=Although fetid pus is not uncommon, pulmonary fetor,
#Text=sui generis, is by no means a common symptom.
#Text=I found it in
#Text=only two of twelve hundred patients of the York County Hospital, and it can only be expected to occur in the rarer forms
#Text=of consumption (using the term in its general sense), such as
#Text=the rheumatic consumption I have described, and the bronchial or
#Text=" pituitous consumption " of Gilchrist, in which there is a copious
#Text=purulent expectoration derived solely from the smaller bronchi,
#Text=although the lungs themselves are flabby, or emphysematous, or
#Text=cedematous.
#Text=It follows, from these facts, that there are three distinct kinds of
#Text=pulmonary fetor, namely, that of faces, that of ozaena, and that of
#Text=gangrene ; and it remains to ascertain how each arises.
#Text=The odour of pulmonary gangrene is obviously due to putrescent
#Text=decomposition of the dead pulmonary tissue; it is the odour of
#Text=putrefaction.
#Text=Dr Law has expressed the opinion that the blood
#Text=previously effused into the lung putrefies.
#Text=This may be the case when
#Text=the lung itself is gangrenous, but blood rarely thus putrefies per se
#Text=— perhaps never — without the action of a septic " ferment."
#Text=It is
#Text=well known that putrid meat will quickly induce putrescence in
#Text=fresh meat when brought near to it or in contact with it ; and it is
#Text=therefore conceivable that the effused blood in cases of pneumonia
#Text=and pulmonary apoplexy of a low type may receive a septic
#Text="ferment" from without, and thus the putrid fermentation be set
#Text=up in it.
#Text=Or it is possible that some of the infusorial organisms
#Text=wiiich seem to be associated with hospital gangrene and other kinds
#Text=of infectious putrescence may take effect on the blood or pulmonary
#Text=tissue.
#Text=In pulmonary mouldiness (the pneumono-mycosis of Vircliow) a parasitic bronchitis seems to result from the irritation of an
#Text=aspergillus in the bronchi.
#Text=These have been found also surrounding the margin of a gangrenous cavity in the lung.
#Text=The
#Text=pulmonary moulds are not unknown to phthisis, and it seems
#Text=probable that the sporules may multiply in the bronchi, and be
#Text=diffused by the breath of the patient, so as to excite a bronchitis in
#Text=those persons who inhale them who have weak lungs.
#Text=Hence,
#Text=perhaps, the widespread belief, that it is not safe to sleep with a
#Text=phthisical person, and that phthisis is a dangerously infectious
#Text=complaint, as is the opinion in Italy.
#Text=The putrescent infusoria,
#Text=such as the vibrios of hospital gangrene and the bacterides of
#Text=carbuncular gangrene, have not, I think, been looked for in cases
#Text=of pulmonary gangrene.
#Text=The bacterides may, however, be a cause
#Text=of those kinds in wliich the gangrenous cavity has no contact with
#Text=the external air and there is no fetor, inasmuch as they are abundantly present in the blood in carbuncular gangrene, and which
#Text=sometimes affects the lungs.
#Text=Since Laennec first mooted the opinion, the ozena-odour in
#Text=certain forms of bronchorrhoea and bronchitis has been attributed
#Text=by several observers to a putrescence of the bronchial excretions.
#Text=Granting this, the inquiry naturally follows, why they become putrescent in tlie particular class of cases described, amongst the many
#Text=thousands who suffer from puralent bronchial secretion ?
#Text=Besides,
#Text=the odour evolved is not at all like that of the fetid pus expectorated in cases of empyema, in which the cavity communicates with a
#Text=bronchus, so that if the purulent bronchial excretion do undergo
#Text=change, there must be something in its composition in these cases
#Text=of a special character.
#Text=That it does undergo decomposition seems
#Text=certain ; but it does not follow that the change is putrefaction.
#Text=In
#Text=ozaena from ulceration of the nasal cartilages, and in rodent fibroid
#Text=ulcers, there is a most offensive discharge, but the odour is not like
#Text=the smell of decomposing pus from ordinary ulcers.
#Text=The pus of
#Text=fibroid pyogenic cavities and of fetid bronchitis undergoes a similar
#Text=change.
#Text=We are therefore led to the conclusion that in all these
#Text=cases there is some special constituent of the morbid products which
#Text=either undergoes its own peculiar decomposition or acts as a ferment
#Text=in exciting such in the other constituents.
#Text=I do not think we need
#Text=go beyond observed facts for instances as to this point.
#Text=In so far
#Text=as anatomical changes have been observed in these fetid pulmonary
#Text=diseases, they are manifestly those of fibrinous exudation and
#Text=degeneration, — are, in short, those which are observed in acute and
#Text=chronic tissue-changes of rheumatic origin.
#Text=Now, we know that
#Text=in such changes lactic acid plays an important part, either as a
#Text=cause if we adopt the conclusions of Dr B.
#Text=W.
#Text=Richardson and
#Text=others, or as a result of the morbid tissue-metamorphosis, if the
#Text=ordinary theory be objected to.
#Text=And it seems farther probable,
#Text=according to the physiological chemists, that it is decomposed in
#Text=the lungs, under ordinary circumstances, into carbonic acid and
#Text=water.
#Text=If, then, we suppose that there is an excess of lactic acid
#Text=in the pulmonary excretions in these cases, or of some other acid of
#Text=the class, or that the ordinary series of decompositions is interrupted
#Text=and other products result in virtue of vital changes, an irritant is
#Text=brought into direct contact with the bronchial mucous membrane.
#Text=If this be sufficiently powerful, the same consequences will follow
#Text=as with other powerful irritants (such as the vapours of iodine or
#Text=chlorine), and tlius a bronchitis with a copious muco-purulent discharge be excited.
#Text=How easily lactic acid or acids or the lactates
#Text=may be transformed within the capillary bronchi and air-cells, or
#Text=elsewhere, wherever a suitable ferment is introduced or produced, is
#Text=shown by the fact that when lactates are left in contact with putrefying matter, at a temperature of 86° to 95°, butyric acid is formed.
#Text=That a rheumatic condition is an important element in these cases
#Text=is shown by collateral evidence, although the morbid product need
#Text=not necessarily be lactic acid, and certainly is not in all cases of
#Text=pulmonary fetor.
#Text=It is incidentally mentioned that in Dr Haldane ' s
#Text=case tube-casts of the smaller bronchi were at first mistaken for
#Text=disintegrating lung-tissue.
#Text=Now these cases of " plastic bronchitis "
#Text=run a course almost identical with that of cases of fetid bronchopneumonia.
#Text=There is the same frequency of haemorrhage, violent
#Text=cough, and other important symptoms, occun-ing in paroxysms,
#Text=lasting for a week or two, but sometimes for several weeks, with the
#Text=same tendency to recur for weeks or years.
#Text=They also end in a
#Text=very similar manner, either in a form of phthisis or in a dangerous
#Text=pulmonary complication, and they are about equally rare.
#Text=In
#Text=short, substitute for expectoration of plastic tube-casts a fetid mucopurulent expectoration, and the diseases would be identical, — so
#Text=that the constitutional conditions are apparently the same.
#Text=The
#Text=difiference is as to the susceptibility of the morbid pulmonary excretions and exudations to undergo decomposition.
#Text=These cases of
#Text=plastic bronchitis shade off also into that special kind of lobar bronchopneumonia, closely resembling the fetid kind in symptoms and
#Text=course, and occurring in rheumatic subjects, to wliicli I liave already
#Text=referred.
#Text=A case of this kind is now under my care in the Infirmary, in which the seat of lesion is (as is most common) in the
#Text=left lung, with persistent pain there, and tingling in the palm of
#Text=the left hand.
#Text=The patient (a man) has had profuse stronglysmelling sweats, like those of the. rheumatic, and rheumatic
#Text=corpuscles in his urine.
#Text=Fetor of the breath closely resembling that under consideration
#Text=is observed in pregnancy, scorbutus, and cachectic states of a rheumatic character ; in all these the blood is highly fibrinous and
#Text=embolism not uncommon.
#Text=Since the pulmonary artery has been
#Text=found plugged in cases of pulmonary gangrene and rodent pulmonary ulcer simulating it, tlie plugging has been usually considered as the cause of the morbid change.
#Text=There seems to be,
#Text=however, just as solid ground for the opposite theory, namely, that
#Text=the plugging is caused by the pulmonary disease.
#Text=But, however
#Text=caused, the excess of fibrin is probably a predisposing or exciting
#Text=cause of the fetor.
#Text=These remarks refer chiefly to cases of pulmonary fetor in which
#Text=changes of structure have been observed.
#Text=But in one class of
#Text=these affections there is no cognisable disease, and yet a very
#Text=characteristic odour (the faecal) is exhaled.
#Text=But these cases, when
#Text=examined, only serve to show more clearly its rheumatic origin.
#Text=In offensive perspiration of the feet a peculiar cabbage-like stench
#Text=is given off.
#Text=It has been roundly asserted that this is due simply
#Text=to want of cleanliness, just as the stench of fetid bronchitis has
#Text=been attributed to gangrene ; but the theory is certainly not sound.
#Text=Cases occur in which the most scrupulous cleanliness fails to prevent
#Text=the smell.
#Text=Indeed, I know no more intractable malady, for even when
#Text=the stockings and shoes are changed two or three times a-day and
#Text=powerful scents used, the morbid stench is still diffused.
#Text=It seems
#Text=probable that the perspiration contains an element which undergoes
#Text=decomposition at a low temperature or on exposure to the air.
#Text=I
#Text=have been informed that a surgeon in extensive practice in the
#Text=north of England committed suicide a few years ago because of
#Text=this offensive malady.
#Text=A patient soon infects the air of a large
#Text=room.
#Text=In the cases that have come under my observation I could
#Text=trace distinctly a rheumatic habit, and sometimes rheumatism was
#Text=a complication.
#Text=Allied to this is the offensive odour in some
#Text=forms of rheumatic fever and in cases of acute recuiTcnt attacks
#Text=of leprous inflammation of the skin, in which the paroxysm terminates by a copious plastic exudation into the cutaneous cellular tissue.
#Text=The urine sometimes becomes fetid in like manner.
#Text=Dr Low, of
#Text=King ' s Lynn, had communicated to me the particulars of a case of
#Text=this kind in a pregnant female, and which ceased with delivery.
#Text=Speculations have naturally arisen as to the immediate origin
#Text=and composition of the volatile matter which causes the stench;
#Text=and as the blood is easily impregnated with volatile stuff, it is
#Text=readily concluded that it comes from the blood.
#Text=Perhaps it may
#Text=be so as to some ; but I think it equally probable as to others,
#Text=that they first become what we find them on exposure to the air in
#Text=the lungs at a blood-heat, or on the surface of the body, as in cases
#Text=of fetid perspiration.
#Text=The change in smell which the fetid sputa
#Text=undergo on exposure to the air shows how easily decomposition
#Text=takes place.
#Text=Possibly the faecal odour may be an excretion, but if
#Text=it were so in my first observed case, it did not originate in any
#Text=so-called metastasis, for I noted the state of the faeces as to odour
#Text=and observed no change.
#Text=Pus from abscesses in the abdominal
#Text=parietes has been found to be highly faecal in smell, although the
#Text=most careful examination failed to detect any connexion between
#Text=the abscess and the intestines.
#Text=I have no doubt that sulphur is
#Text=a predominant, albeit not exclusive constituent of these fetid volatile changes.
#Text=The odour itself is a sufficient proof, independently
#Text=of distillations of sputa at a temperature of 230° Fahr. ; and I may
#Text=add that ordinary pulmonary vapour itself, if collected and kept
#Text=a while, quickly becomes fetid, and even the condensed vapours on
#Text=the windows of rooms crowded with people smells offensively
#Text=although the highest temperature cannot exceed 90°.
#Text=Dr Gamgee
#Text=has, however, demonstrated, what was already plain enough to all

#Text=acquainted with the facts, that we can get stinks from any pulmonary excretion whatever, if we subject them to the same chemical torments of distillation, acidification, neutralization, redistillation, and the like.
#Text=This fact is no ground, however, for the

#Text=conclusions, that there is nothing special in the odour of fetid bronchitis or its causes, and that we must abandon that term as perplexing, unscientific, and unphilosophical, for the more correct
#Text=phrase " bronchitis with fetid expectoration."
#Text=I have, however,
#Text=subjoined reports of the chemical analysis of the sputum in two
#Text=cases under my care.
